commentBody: Nice challenge; fun theme
Sometimes my brain just…can’t.
Completed fairly quickly without really getting the theme. Read the article afterwards and feel like the theme is a bit weak, but what do I know?
I got the idea here fairly quickly (that doesn't always happen!) and enjoyed passing the IT around. The SW corner was a little harder for me because MINIMAP, but now I know the term.
I thought this was a gem! I love the theme.
That was something enjoyable.  Took me a while to figure out that I was passing it back and forth.  Which sounds a little naughty depending on the context. Happy Thursday!!

OMNOMNOM? That's an answer?
Oh no no no.
Wow! Very fun and challenging.

Just over twice my normal Thursday solving time!  I was able to keep filling in theme answers by putting normal English words in, and the theme became apparent quickly enough.  But the non-theme clues were seemingly from an entirely different universe than where I live, sort of like the old Twilight Zone episode called “The Parallel”.

Really fun puzzle.  I didn’t really get going until the clever gimmick clicked for me.  Once I got “it” the puzzle came together. I was a little disappointed that there were several answers that had appeared recently: DROPTROU, GOGO, ARSENIO, although the clue for DROPTROU was clever.  But there were some fun clues, especially result of cord cutting for INNIE, like a doormat for TOONICE, and sign of terrible service for NOBARS (as a former restaurant worker I tried no tips first).
So clever! Great solve.

Haha, I enjoy these themes where the unclued word appearing in the grid just *might* somehow fit the clue in a weird way.

Isaac Newton wrote about GRAVY? Sure! Alchemy was all the rage. I’m sure it was an ongoing quest to find the exact right ratio of fat and thickener.

A SUBTITLE is not obvious? Sure!  How about “Easy Ten Minute Recipes: the complete, unabridged, comprehensive guide”

The minty Cuban cocktail is MOJO? Sure! Just have enough of them.

This is the kind of puzzle that makes me want to stop wasting my time. Not funny, amusing or interesting, just a constructor's ego to be fed. Of course as a Canadian, I am in a bad mood with all things American these days.

Fun solve!   Great refresh after a tough day.   Enjoyed the clever theme, the amusing clues,and OMNOMNOM (which my  son said a lot as a teen ).  Plus  got a good laugh from Deb's "She overthought everything" comment...

I really, really enjoyed this puzzle, all the way from actually doing it, to going back and figuring out things like "Why is the constructor so sure brits are a smart set.  I mean, after all, Boris Johnson?  

So when I got it it gave me a shot of delight, more so than usual.

Bravissimo!
Very playful. Such a fun solve!

I suspect we're going to see a lot of complaints about the puzzle "not crediting my rebuses".

Or wondering why (as I did for quite a while) BRITAIN has exclusively smart bunch of people?  (Brexit, anyone?)
This was such a nice puzzle! Intuitive trick to the theme, fun wordplay, and it was cool to see internet lingo like omnomnom. 🫶
Om nom nom nom nom nom nom. <- *me eating a CREPE*

Tough but fair. 

Nice wordplay theme with solid theme answers. 

OMNOMNOM!

"You know about circuits?"
"Oh, yeah, I read up on current events!"

("Wire you so amped up?")

I first solved it with rebuses: MOJ(ITO), using only the last rebus letter for the downs. I didn't get the music. I kept hesitating over OMNOMNOM. I would have preferred "nomnomnom," but it was too long, and I liked the crosses I had. I removed the rebuses and voila—music. 

Welcome, Mr. Lively.

What a delicious, delightful puzzle. 
OMNOMNOM!

Congratulations on a fun NYT debut, Mr. Lively!

This was one of those puzzles where I just had to trust that eventually, it would become clear why certain answers didn’t fit their clues. Somewhere between the halfway point and three-fourths, it clicked.

Thanks!
Nice one! Well done.
Great debut puzzle, Brad!  A perfect Thursday for me,  both fun and challenging.

I enjoyed this puzzle. Picked up on the theme pretty quickly. My one quibble is with the clue for SEE. To "grok" is much deeper than simply seeing. In fact, I'm guessing the reason it has been adopted into English is because we don't have a word that means the same thing. Or maybe we do and I just don't know it.  Anyone?
Just had to DROP in (TROU still on) to say that I absolutely loved this. Clever, playful, and challenging, it was the perfect puzzle to wake up to this morning. Thanks, Brad!

Great puzzle.

Great moment when I finally decided to stuff the IT into SUBTLE and discovered the new word formed. 

I love a Thursday where you think you [grok] the trick that’s being played only to go on to SEE there’s more to the theme than you originally thought. 

Thanks for the good time, Brad Lively
Cute theme! Drop trou was a new one for me.

Mr. Lively, how appropriate your surname is for this puzzle! Congratulations on a very clever debut, playing ping-pong with us! Unfortunately, I dropped the ball at the G of GO LONG, having no idea *ever* about sports terms. I even thought a [Passing remark] might be sOLONG. The cross didn't help me since I had no clue as to what Ed.D. meant. But none of that mattered. It was a tiny glitch for me in an otherwise fabulous solving experience. Thank you so much! ............................................... The musical accompaniment for me today was "Stadium Arcadium" by the Red Hot Chili Peppers, just because ARCADE always makes me think of that song, despite the words having entirely different meanings and origins. Still, this puzzle did have for me that paradise quality - harmonius, tranquil, peaceful - that "Arcadium" implies. https://youtu.be/j9qfClVvfIw?si=9hgc5ifiLsGN54-k

Hmm... First time I've read this, and I read it after I worked the puzzle. It seems like if you read it before the puzzle, that it virtually works the puzzle for you. I thought for a Thursday puzzle, this one was pretty easy. I think I was helped on some clues by being fairly fluent in Spanish, and reasonably knowledgeable about French. I know almost nothing about, and actually detest, football, but I got the "passing remark" clue. I thought this was a fun puzzle, but then maybe that's because I could actually work it.

Man it took me a bit to realize it was drop trou haha

Great puzzle, got the theme pretty quickly. Enjoyed.

Really enjoyed this one, although I won’t admit to the time “it” took to complete— especially since I caught on fairly quickly to the gimmick! Nevertheless, this was one of those I sometimes despaired of completing: I hung on to NOtipS for 45D for wa-a-a-y too long, despite being pretty sure that 60A had to be ROEPER— 🤦🏻‍♀️. (It always surprises me at how dense I am capable of being, once the correct answers fall into place!) Hope to see more from this constructor!

This was cute and fun. Lively, even.

I like how GRAVY, RYE, OAT and CREPE feed right into OMNOMNOM.

Similarly, I suppose it’s fitting that (rhymes with) tEXTING, SNORTS and a broken MOJITO lead one to DROP TROU. I have a feeling that the Mouse House up above would disapprove.
It was a fun and clever puzzle. Except for 60A, which I consider Gene Siskel erasure. Two thumbs way down!

I rarely enjoy a challenge but today forced myself to complete the puzzle without any lookups, and I did it!

I'm actually quite proud of myself - there was a lot of trivia in the grid today, and also American expressions (like GO LONG), most of either unknown to me, or unfamiliar as clued, at least (for example, I got ARSENIO with enough crosses, even though the clue was arcanely mysterious to me, with the Dog Pound thing).

I also got the theme, which restored some of my faith in my own intellect - I usually have problems parsing words differently and seeing connections between words.when trickery us involved. I enjoyed how all the themed entries where actuak words rather than gibberish. Cool stuff.

I may have a pedantic nit to pick with DRACULA - the original Romanian was DRACULeA, I think? Wikipedia confirms my suspicion. The clue implying the answer will be in Romanian is a mistake.

Still, that is not as bad as something my wife encountered in a non-NYT American crossword recently, where Serb was clued as... Kosovo resident. Now, I know some Serbs reside in Kosovo, but given the Kosovans' struggle for independence, the fact Serbia does not recognize it, and generally how important and dangerous ethnic tension has always been in the Balkans, that was an incredibly ill-coceived clue: not as bad as, say, 1944 Warsaw resident: German, but getting there.
Loved this puzzle! Had to google what "drop trou" meant and then felt as though I'd known the phrase my whole life.
I never know how to reply to a question with my mouth full. At least now, I know how to spell it.
Didn’t get the trick until I read the column - quite clever.   Missing the 7pm appearance of the puzzle  on my east coast trip.
That was very cute, very cute indeed.

Very enjoyable again. 
I tried to fit and 'it' somewhere into DROP TROU because that seemed nonsensical, but it's a real expression! But then I thought TARPITS was a real word.
I'd forgotten all about having 'no service' with NOBARS, I don't think it has happened to me for ages. I haven't been out on any moors or mountains for a long time.

Nice debut, Brad.  It's very ambitious to shoot for a Thursday.

The trick was fun to figure out and should satisfy the anti-rebus crowd.

[Provide a brief glimpse?] for DROP TROU and [One on a sic list?] for TYPO were favorites.

At the end, I spent some time pondering which letter to put in the CENAC/MINIMAP cross, but after thinking about the options, N made the most sense.  I was less than 100% sure of that, so I was happy to see that I made the right choice.
I thought this was a fun clever puzzle.  Omnomnom gave me a chuckle.  Nice debut, Mr. Lively!
This was too cute and clever for my simple brain.

I got VOLTRON with minimal crosses purely because I thought it sounded like a plausible name for a giant robot. I never heard of the show.

Overall, I made tons of risky leaps and assumptions that normally would have left me stumped after ending up with so many incorrect crosses that I woyld have been unable to see the patterns of the unanswered entries. Somehow I got away with that today, though, and finished quickly with no lookups.

Took me a little while to get “it”, but once I did, I thought it was going to be smooth sailing through the rest of the puzzle, but no.  The SW slowed me down at the end.  Had to correct the first letter of OMNOMNOM.

Two traps I fell into: I had “suitable” in mind where “subtitle” should go and had such a hard time unthinking that first thought; “too nice” was a huge dook for me, I had a hard time getting away from toon ice.

Drop trou will always evoke a fond memory for me. Near the end of my first concert tour abroad, one that had been over-programmed, our ensemble was worn to a frazzle and running on fumes. We gathered on stage to warm up for our concert in Munich, and there was no there there. I thought the concert would be a complete disaster. We changed into our formal attire and gathered outside for our pep talk from the stage manager, whose job it was to get us psyched up. He stood in the middle of our circle quietly taking us all in with his eyes, then simply dropped trou. We all broke up laughing, all of our tension and tiredness fell away, and we sang one of the best concerts of the tour.

I solved a Thursday without lookups under my average time (just barely)! It’s been a while. I’m starting to see the value of patience. It’s so satisfying to solve a (hard for me) puzzle! Lots of educated guesses today that worked out. Congrats on a chewy and enjoyable debut, Brad!

And Deb, you are not alone in the overthinking department. I’m right there with ya!

Do emus overthink everything?

STRANDS THREAD
No spoilers until after View All Replies, please.
Strands #389
“Playing the field”
🔵🔵🔵🟡
🔵🔵🔵

Not sure if anyone's still interested in this.
Thought this one apt.

Fun puzzle and a good workout. Actually caught on to the trick fairly early and enjoyed pondering to finally catch on to each of the theme answers. And... must admit I had to cheat on OMNOMNOM - That is completely unfamiliar and even with some crosses I had to look it up to confirm. Fun puzzle find today. A Thursday from May 17, 2001 by David J. Kahn. Some theme clue and answer examples: "Swedish tennis star's favorite movie?" BJORNFREE "Singer who really cuts the mustard?" CELINEDIJON "Vehicle for touring Scandinavia?" FJORDEXPLORER And the reveal: "Coxcombs (and a hint to solving this puzzle)" POPINJAYS Here's the Xword Info link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/17/2001&g=55&d=A I'm done. .....
Great fun! I had an inkling about it with Sir Isaac, and tasted it with MOJitO.
Kudos to Christina Iverson for her Strands puzzle today. It was really quite clever, both in its concept and layout!
I got the theme quite quickly, but for me the southwest corner was one big natick.

This was a capital-P Puzzle for me, with tricky clues making many answers slow to slap down, which in turn made the theme slow to crack.  Capital-P Puzzles transport my brain to its delicious I-love-this-kind-of-work place, and then, when the box finally fills in, it feels good through and through.

Observations:
•	An elegant touch is that the only answers in the grid that contain IT are theme answers.
•	Sweet to see GO LONG in a puzzle with a theme about passing.
•	Also sweet:  the rhyming neighborhood with SEER, LEER, and SNEER.
•	[Result of some cord cutting, informally] for INNIE – gold!

A debut that felt like the work of a pro – color me impressed.  Thank you for this, Brad, it was a capital-P Pleasure.  Congratulations, and may there be more to come!

A glorious debut  that has *it* all! 

OMNOMNOM? 
C’mon. That’s even fun to type!
And how did I know it when I didn’t actually know it?

I love that about language.
If you understand it, it works.
If it works, it’s language.

My husband loads the dishwasher so…wrong.
He has dish-ues.
And I have issues with his dish-ues.

I was crucivibing all the way through
this spicy, saucy Thursday.

Thank you Mr. Lively for this gift!

Cool! The rare-in-crosswords s’moresdinlap,
which is a word that in both directions sounds like your mouth is full of marshmallows and chocolate…
or toon ice.


( wink to Lewis :)

It took me quite a while to figure out what was going on, but it ended up being the first of the theme answers that finally got me started. Once I got those, it was mostly smooth sailing, until the SW tripped me up for a while. I did put the right letters in, so...finished. 

But LET ME UP seemed rude, and OMNOMNOM just didn't work for this oldster. I could have been content with NOMNOMNOM, but nooooo.

I guess I'm the only one tonight solving pen on paper, .pdf version. The font looked weird before I printed it, but after printing it was so tiny that I really could have used a magnifiying glass. Hope this was just a one-off.

The trick came easy, the SW not so much.

That's the way goes sometimes, eh?

Loved the puzzle, got the theme fairly quickly. But one question about 41D - Like a doormat = too nice? 
Don't understand the answer. Clarification would be appreciated.
Thanks!

The true story, not the apocryphal one: One chill evening in 1680--chill as only evenings in Britain can be--Newton was dining with John Flamsteed and Edmond Halley. Flamsteed was asking Newton about his recent work on optical theory, but Newton's mouth was full, and all he could utter was an "omnomnom" (or was that a  "nomnomnom"? Accounts differ.) Newton was, in fact, helping himself to another serving roast beef, when Halley, whose mouth was parched from that dry-as-dust oatcake, reached for the pitcher of ale, and inadvertently bumped Newton, causing him to spill gravy all over his front ("For every action, there is an equal, but opposite reaction").

And thus Celestial Mechanics was born.

***

Don't get me started on "food sensitivities," but I gotta drop in to say that, although OATS do not contain gluten*, they are frequently eschewed but persons striving to keep a gluten-free lifestyle. Oats are frequently processed in mills which also process gluteny grains, and cross-contamination is considered possible. Some companies offer "certified gluten-free" oats, for which they charge more. 

*unlike RYE and barley, both of which contain more gluten than wheat. It's amazing how many people--chefs included--don't realize this. And yet they live.
This was a tricky one, I knew there was something with the missing "IT"s, but I didn't make the connection with the extra letters on the other clues until I read the blog!
Completely baffled at the answer to "smart sort."  Could someone please explain the solution to me?  (I worked it out but I do not understand it.)

I was puzzled until suddenly IT all made sense. Isn’t that just the best kind of puzzle?

Congratulations, Brad, on a very impressive debut.
Why is the type so small on hardcopy version? PLEASE don't let this happen again!!!

Clever theme utterly ruined (for me) by ROEPER/ETAPE.

I stopped paying attention once Gene Siskel passed in 1999, and I am neither fluent in French nor a devotee of cycling. 

So I failed with ROEGER/ETAGE. Tough crossing that one, since ETAGE is actually a word in French. Just not the right one here.

Not a fan of the puzzle's form either, with essentially three separate parts glues together with DROPTROU and the utterly silly OMNOMNOM.

OK, letting it go now. Some nice elements here, but won't be calling it a favorite any time soon.
Nive and Lively solve for a Thursday morning, loved the clever theme.   Thanks Brad!

Thought this was really clever. Was stuck at about 60% complete because while I could see how IT was omitted in italicized clues, I wasn’t connecting the back/forth of IT. Once that (finally) dawned on me, the puzzle pretty much completed itself. 

I love Thursday puzzles.

Congratulations on your debut, Brad. IT was a pleasure to work IT out. Cracked up entering OMNOMNOM - did anyone else picture Cookie Monster or was it just me? 🍪🍪🤣 Great start to my Thursday morning, so thank you ☺️

Excellent debut! Thursday is my favorite day, too, and this did not disappoint. The theme was clever, but not too difficult to parse before I finished my coffee.

It had tons of fun fill as well: DRACULA, ARSENIO, MINIMAP, VOLTRON, OM NOM NOM!

Congrats!

Really enjoyed this Thursday puzzle!
Loved that it came with two separate 'A-ha!' moments: the first quite early on when I realized that the 'IT' was left out of the clues with 'pass it on', and then the second after much head scratching when I realized the 'IT' was actually 'passed along' to other clues. 🤦‍♂️
Congratulations on a great debut!

First:  anyone else have to scrounge around for a magnifier?  Or, as I did, "print on two pages" (except I just printed the page with the MUCH LARGER clues.)  That was unbelievable.

Clever trick, wonderful puzzle!... EXCEPT FOR THE MINIATURE CLUES!  

I did go astray early on, at 6D by entering JAWOHL (thinking, "Wow, these crossings are going to be really something!")  It's not always a plus to know other languages.

I couldn't remember Roger Ebert's film buddy Gene's last name (or, at least, the spelling) --if I ever saw the names printed out--and it crossed an unknown cartoon robot --my guesses were VOLTRAN or VOLTRON.  Seemed a bit unfair, given how long-gone the film critics' show is....   I picked the wrong letter.  Oh, well.  I got all of the essential clue/entry pairs (the "Fun Four"!)

In other news, it was so nice to see David Connell chiming in after a hiatus.  So many of our crew from past years have moved on (such as Pecantart, Leapy, and of course sad losses like Mac and his bird photos...)  

See youse guys tomorrow, if it comes.
OMNOMNOM?  Utterly ridiculous

I wanted 7A to be SOLONG, as in when you pass someone in a race you go "so long sucka!"

Awesome puzzle though, love to have the fun gimmicks back on a Thursday, with clever cluing!

This was cute and fun. Lively, even.

I like how GRAVY, RYE, OAT and CREPE feed right into OMNOMNOM.

Similarly, I suppose it’s fitting that S*XTING (edited to thwart the emu police), SNORTS and a broken MOJITO lead one to DROP TROU. I have a feeling that the Mouse House up above would disapprove.
Thank goodness for so many helpful hints from so many puzzlers. Very grateful!

Loved the Thursday trickery here, but I'm not surprised that there's no explanation for, nor mention of 43A in the column or constructor notes. 

I'm all ears for anyone who wants to explain how the first 2 letters make any sense as clued.

Fantastic debut.

Mr. Lively will be a TAN of this industry if he can COMPOSITE more puzzles like this.
What a fun and clever debut! Wasn't sure at first what to do with MOJitO, and why anyone eould do CIRCUITS in a tent, but then GRAVY clinched it for me. Who doesn't love gravy? Luscious puzzle
The Knights who say "Ni!" wish to complain about this puzzle, and also to say "Ni!" to the constructor. I thought it was fine. Oh no, now I've said it! I've said it again!

Comedian Wyatt Cenac is an amazement of dry humor, deadpan, irony, self-parody. He plays the lead in the unfortunately short-lived series “People of Earth” and it is hilarious. Oh, for a third season!

If the name Wyatt Cenac doesn’t ring a bell,
and if you like dry, droll humor,
look him up!

So glad to see most liked this puzzle! Me, too! Clever and smart.
It's just a VAPE, RYE, MOJITO, CREPE, ICEE, GRAVY, ALE,  SEXTING, SNORTS, SNEERS, LEERs, DROPTROU CIRCUS of a heath food and good etiquette kind of a day!! 
OMNOMNOM!

I loved the misdirect at 6-Down: Affirmative reply to "Sprechen Sie Englisch?"

I trust I wasn't the only one who thought that the answer had to be in German.
But I had confidently entered DISNEY in 1-Across, and I don't think there are any German words that begin with "Y".
And certainly the "House of Mouse" can't end with a "J".

Very clever!
Brad you are too smart for me man
Tricky one! Had to brute force the ETAPE/ROEPER natick to get the gold star

A lot of the cluing was great, lots of clever misdirection. Some of the fill was bad, like OMNOMNOM? The gimmick came to me pretty quickly. Yesterday’s baseball theme was more impressive but maybe it spoiled me for the week.

TROU seems to have come up a lot, recently. It's unknown to me, and DROP TROU doubly so, both linguistically and socially.
When does one DROP TROU? (I'm assuming it refers to situations other than routine undressing.) And is it pronounced like the first syllable of "trousers", or like "trew"?
This puzzle could also be titled "Take It Away."
Throughout the solve kept thinking, "What's IT all about?"   Nice one.
That was fun!
Can someone please explain the answer "Britain?"  I don't see the connection with the clue.  Thanks
Two soundtracks for today's puzzle, for persons with tastes both Black and Slim: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=glpIgnmKrZc https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bxHjytBY7Z8
OMNOMNOM; oh my no.

DROPping TROU was a phrase (and activity) that I had never heard of growing up in the Northeast.

But in my first year teaching in Kentucky, a colleague told me how she(!?!) got her class's attention by standing on her desk and dropping trou!  I had to ask for an explanation.
I was aghast!

I'm sure that, whatever her point was, her students will remember it for the rest of their lives.
Excellent puzzle with terrific cluing -- great job Brad!
Whew— A GOOD One!

This was fun for me. Like others, I got part of the trick and then a bit later got the rest of it.

If I hadn't at first spelled scoot with a K, I would have been able to handle the movie critic and French word cross much sooner.

Oh well. I can just barely spell. 

Still, coming in at 31 minutes for me, this felt somewhat easy but not in a bad way. Applying the trick to the various clues was entertaining, and it was satisfying that knowing the trick helped with some of the entries.

I got mojito really quickly to change to mojo, but it took me a while to get that i needed those "it" letters in the other answer with circus. So that turned out to be pretty fun. Now, I'll read the journalism part of the nyt and be horrified at reality again.
Challenging but fun. Got stuck on telecom request until I changed the the last preposition from in to up.
ETAPE was my downfall.  Never heard of it.

Fun trick. 

Still, done in 15. Hope for more challenge from a Thursday.

That was a nice puzzle, congrats to the constructor! 

For me, I had just a few lookups. Also, I did not know GROK and had "minemap" before realizing it was MINIMAP. I only got half the theme. I realized the IT was removed but didn't understand the passing back and forth. That's on me, though. I'm disappointed in myself because I recall a recent puzzle with AorB which was the clue for the entry right next door. I did get the trickery of that puzzle, but for some reason I didn't connect (in today's puzzle) that these were clues involving the next door neighbor as well. I guess it was just too SUBTITLE for me, or perhaps I'm not the BRITAIN I thought I was!

Still impressed with the grid, though. I know I'll grok it next time.

Note from an avid cyclist, and amateur linguist, on ETAPE:

Of course, we *want* it to be "étage," because that's the cognate, and False Friend* of "stage." But it's not: it's "étape," which is cognate to "staple," and, further removed, "staff." Why? Well, to summarize wiktionary:

    A public storehouse--> (by extension) Supplies issued to troops on the march.--> (by extension) The place where troops on the march halt overnight.--> (by extension) The distance marched during a day.--> (by extension, cycling) A stage of a multistage bicycle race.

That's a long way for a word to ride, just to get the yellow jersey!

*The kind of Friend which lets you draft from them, and perhaps offers you a swig from their water-bottle; but in the end will cut you off at the last bend, and land you in the ditch:-(
Is there a reason the clues are in 5-point type today? Eye test? Magnifier sale?
I always solve first with the list of clues, not looking at the crossword itself. Made that "it" trick a real doozy to crack haha.

OMNOMNOM?

Had to look it up, and then realized it's a contemporary equivalent to Yum Yum.

Is it really the case (as one source asserts) that the phrase originated with Cookie Monster on Sesame Street?
Tough but fair.
GOLONG crossing with GRE and OSX is very poor construction.  The 3-letter abbreviations are getting excessive and OOLONG could have avoided one of them.  I did enjoy the theme though.

I could not have finished this puzzle without coming to the column to for Deb's explanation of why only wrong fills were working to advance the solve.  After I got it, there wasn't a lot o be done, and that part was fun.  Still scratching my head over the goofiness of it all, especially at Newton's GRAVY.

This was a dazzler of a debut, Brad, and certainly a Lively one.  Your brain seems to go headlong down paths not normally taken and to do cartwheels of inventiveness.  I dare you to try to construct a Monday
OMNOMNOM?????  Absurd.
I’ll die on the hill that Thursday gimmicks should be abolished in Crosswords. Still, though, I found the rest of this puzzle enjoyable!

"Event in a tent" requires a singular answer. "CIRCUITS" is plural.
What am I missing?
Not sure if anyone has mentioned it yet, but can we get a hats (caps?) off to the developers for today’s Strands grid? Bravo! 👏👏👏
Fun one!

The only part that really stumped me was ETAPE / ROEPER -- I thought surely "estage" made sense as the French for stage, and "Roeger" sounded plausibly name-like.

Also, once I realized there needed to be an "IT" removed from the answer, I was stuck on "invitee" instead of VISITOR for 42A, despite "invee" not being a word.

Otherwise I got through this fairly steadily! And for what it's worth, I got OMNOMNOM as soon as I saw a couple of the letters. It's been a common onomatopoeia for like... 20 years?
Did anyone mention that the online solution to this puzzle is incomplete? The last line is missing.
Why is "event in a tent" circuits?

A great debut! The theme was confusing at first, even after I thought I had it figured out, but eventually the mists cleared and I was on my way. I felt the fill was just a touch harder than usual, with not a lot of crosswordese, which was refreshing. One day, I'm going to remember the word for a Tour de France stage - one day. Thanks for the fun!

In response to accusations that Brad Lively was feeding his own ego, by that logic we would all be feeding our own egos when we solve crossword puzzles. We come to the puzzles to accept a challenge that we are as clever as the constructor, and for people who guard their streaks and times, to vie for some kind of superiority over other solvers.

There are puzzles that drive me crazy with clues I can't figure out or fills that I just don't know, but ultimately I accept that the lack is mine. Blaming the constructor is to blame the messenger.

I really enjoyed this!

Also liked that the clue for "gluten-free grain" cam after the answer RYE (a gluten grain!)
With all the gamers posting defenses of this puzzle, that tells me it was borderline at best.  Here's hoping Friday's won't be quite so its-y.
I’m sorry to everyone that winced as they entered OMNOMNOM, but I was thrilled when I saw it begin to come together. Brilliant debut!
I really liked the theme and overall solving experience. 43A reminded me of the Simpsons.

This was fun. I like unusual tricks like this 'IT' one, revealing themselves as other clues are solved. That said, I found several of the other clues quite challenging. Is "Drop Trou" seriously a phrase, or just made to fit this puzzle? Aerospace engineer behind this one... adds up :) Congrats on your debut!
Fun puzzle! Not too happy with OMNOMNOM though…definitely the biggest reach on an answer I’ve encountered in a while.

Oh, I thought this was a whole lot of fun! Got a kick out of the clever theme and enjoyed the fill. 

I kind of blew my average time on it because I forgot to turn off the clock during the parts of my work meeting that I actually had to pay attention to. Heh heh. Guess that's what I get for being such a terrible employee. 😉 

Anyhow, it was a long day, though a fine one, so I haven't read any of the comments yet. I hope people enjoyed this as much as I did!
My favorite puzzle in a long time! Brilliant debut. So much fun!
49D (ETAPE) and 60A (ROEPER) broke my 21 day no-lookups streak.

Just drove 6000km from Alberta through Montana, Idaho, Utah, Arizona, Nevada to spend 3 weeks in sunny SoCal then back north through the beautiful Napa Valley, Avenue of the Giants, Oregon coast, Washington, British Columbia and back to Alberta. It was a CIRCUIT and a (weather) CIRCUS. We found everyone very gracious to their northern neighbours but saw only a rare Canadian license plate. I fear this will be the case for the next number of years.

Oh well color me today I learned(TIL)! Thanks to Brad as that was a highlight of the week.

When I was about 15 I read "The Kingdom and the Power" by Gay Talese, a history of the NYT.

In there he mentions a conversation with John Kennedy, in which he used a bad word that you can get by ridding "fire truck" of a few letters.  

I was aghast that a man of his position would use language like that.

@Jane Wheelaghan 

In the spirit of the Opening Day of baseball: 

When it starts to rain, and play is suspended, the grounds crew covers the infield (that is, the baseball diamond and not the outfield) with a large plastic cover that is otherwise stored on a big roller at the edge of the playing area (in foul territory).

That large plastic cover is universally called a TARPAULIN.  Or a TARP, for short.

The thing I love about musicians is that they always have these cracking stories to tell.

I worked as a software developer who played the bass in gigs around town, as a side line.  He was probably making $100/ hour or more programming.  

One day he got up and left early, saying.  "Got a gig.  Going to make tens of dollars."

There is something magical about music.

Oh.. and one more puzzle find.This one was cute. A Sunday from August 26, 2012 by Amanda Yesnowitz and Doug Peterson with the title; "Put a lid in it." The puzzle had 6 rebus squares which were all the word 'HAT.' A couple of theme answers: 

LADYC(HAT)TERLEYSLOVER*
HORTON(HAT)CHESTHEEGG*
TOCATC(HAT)HIEF*
MA(HAT)MAGANDHI
C(HAT)TANOOGACHOOCHOO*

And all of those answers with asterisks were making their one and only appearance in any puzzle. And... with apologies - the last one I listed reminded me of one of my very favorite punch lines from a joke. A line from Dale Evans: 

Pardon me Roy, is that the cat that chewed your new shoes? 

I'll shut up now.

The puzzle doesn't have a title.
The Wordplay column has a headline.
Only Sunday crosswords have titles.

@Carol BRAIN. With IT in the middle

@Carol 

It is one of the themers.  Take the IT out of BRITAIN, pass it on (to VISOR) and you are left with BRAIN, or [Smart sort], like us.

@Carol 

The IT moves over to 42A VISOR, making the “real” answers BRAIN and VISITOR.
@John Carson does BRAIN really work for “smart sort”? Shouldn’t it be BRAINY?

@D

Probably close enough.  

"He had a BRAIN for figures."

"She was the BRAIN behind that great plan"

@D 

No, [Smart sort] is a noun phrase. It requires a noun or noun phrase for an answer. BRAIN is a noun, not brainy.

Whether or not it originated with Cookie Monster, he's the one who popularized it.  Which may explain why a certain segment of the solving public is unfamiliar with the expression.

On the other hand, I don't think it's an equivalent to Yum Yum.  Yum Yum means something tastes good.  You may say that once you have sampled something. 
Today's phrase simply means that one is in the process of devouring it...I'm not sure Cookie Monster is particularly discriminating.

The letters IT were moved backward or forward depending on the adjacent clue. So CIRCUS became…
@Emily It’s CIRCUS; The ‘IT’ is being transferred from the clue across from it. This happens four times, so eight words will appear to not match the clue until you realize the theme.

@Jamie S 
It's a Robert Heinlein reference, to his novel "Stranger In A Strange Land", and absolutely not what Heinlein had in mind when he coined the word.

@Oikofuge 

I thought it meant to understand, maybe deeply.

@Renegator
In "Stranger" it had the sense of understanding a person or thing so profoundly that you pretty much assimilated their being into your own. It was also the Martian word for "to drink", which Heinlein offered as a profound analogy for the spiritual process of grokking.

In the way of things, it's had a lot of those associations rubbed off as it has been adopted into general English usage, so now [See] is a perfectly reasonable clue for GROK. 

(Yes, I know I should probably give up on making these passing observations, and just answer people's questions ...)
